text:
The latest 1.3 release works fine on WinXP (XP professional w/ sp1), but 2.0.46 
will not work correctly.  

No errors are reported/logged, but Apache consumes 99% of CPU most of the time 
(sometimes drops to 40%-50%), and browser never successfully connects to Apache.

The thread(s) using all the CPU must not be very hight priority, because even 
when consuming 99%, the computer's desktop is still very responsive.

I've triple-checked the config, and I really don't think I'm doing anything 
wrong, and I've used Apache for years (not a novice) -- but I'm also not immune 
from pulling a Homer (D'OH!).  Any suggestions would be welcome, or 
confirmation that I'm not the only one in the world having this problem.

Thank you.
creator: frank.domina@sciatl.com

text:
Hello Frank,

Do you have McAfee VirusScan running on your machine?

If it is running, you might download the LSP-Fix utility from http://www.cexx.
org/lspfix.htm and use it to remove the cslsp.dll from the WinSock2 protocoll 
stack.

WARNING: this might disable the EMail scanning features of McAfee VirusScan


Reasoning:

McAfee installs an extension to the WinSock2 protocoll stack. It seems that this 
extension does not exactly behave like the standard WinSock2 protocoll stack.

What is this extension used for? I don't know, but I guess it has to do with 
EMail scanning.

Regards,

Thomas
creator: tkl@telenet.ch

text:
No feedback to comments of 6/27, but it does sound like a network stack
  problem.  closing.
creator: wrowe@apache.org
frank.domina@sciatl.com
text:
Yes, I am running McAfee, so it looks like I have to stick with Apache 1.3 
since 1.3 doesn't have a problem with McAfee.  I was hoping this would be 
resolved in 2.x by now.  I appologize for not replying to this much sooner.

creator: nd@perlig.de
text:
It should be resolved in McAffee, which is bugged. Anyway, you might try the
Win32DisableAcceptEx directive.
